subject: Re: [junit] problem reusing fixtures
msgSnippet: All the classic OO tricks still apply... For instance, if you have relatively few (or stable) anA scenarios, template method could works ok. ie. abstract
messageBody:
All the classic OO tricks still apply...

For instance, if you have relatively few (or stable) "anA" scenarios,
template method could works ok.

ie.

abstract class BaseTest extends TestCase
{
private A aUT;
private B bUT;

protected abstract A newATestScenario();
protected abstract B newBTestScenario();

protected void setUpDerivedFixture(){}

public final void setUp()
{
aUT = newATestScenario();
bUT = newBTestScenario();
setUpDerivedFixture();
}

public final void test1() {}
...
public final void testN() {}
}

public final Case1Test extends BaseTest
{
protected final A newATestScenario()
{
return new Case1AImpl();
}
protected final B newBTestScenario()
{
return new Case1BImpl();
}
}

public final Case2Test extends BaseTest
{
protected final A newATestScenario()
{
return new Case2AImpl();
}
protected final B newBTestScenario()
{
return new Case2BImpl();
}
}

etc...

Strategy could work fine too...


public final ATest extends TestCase
{
private A aUT;
private B bUT;

public ATest(A theAUT, B theBUT)
{
aUT = theAUT;
bUT = theBUT;
}

public final void test1() {}
...
public final void testN() {}
}

This approach would probably affect your suite construction, but can
save you pain in other ways...

Regards,
-- Levi

PS> suite construction could look something like this (you mentioned
ints?):

public final class AllTests
{
public Test suite()
{
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

for(int i = 0; i < 100; i++)
{
suite.addTest(new ATest(i));
}
return suite
}
}

> Hi,
>
> I have a TestCase that uses following fixtures and setUp :
>
> protecte A anA;
> protected B aB;
>
> public void setUp() {
> // set up of anA
> // set up of aB based on anA
> }
>
> Then, I have a **bunch** of test methods (tests).
>
> Now, I want reuse these for different kinds of anA.
>
> For, example anA is an int and I want to run
> test for 10 random or specified integers.
>
> What is the simplest way to achieve this ?
>
> I don't find a simple solution.
> Maybe I'm missing something ?
>
> Thanks for any help,
> AG
